questions.text: A 66-year-old man is admitted as an emergency with severe epigastric pain. He smokes 30 cigarettes a day and takes approximately 30 units of alcohol per week, but admits to exceeding this amount occasionally. He also complains of sudden onset of poor vision. Ophthalmoscopy shows multiple microinfarcts (cotton wool spots). What investigation should be considered next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient probably has acute pancreatitis precipitated by alcohol consumption.
  • Ischaemic retinopathy, which causes retinal oedema and microinfarcts, is a complication of acute pancreatitis.
  • A CT scan of the abdomen will be useful in confirming the diagnosis and assessing for the presence of a pancreatic abscess/pseudocyst.

Causes of acute pancreatitis:

  • Gallstones (the most important risk factor) or other biliary diseases
  • heavy alcohol consumption
  • hypertriglyceridemia
  • hypercalcemia
  • Blunt Abdominal Trauma
  • ERCP
  • Drugs: azathioprine, mercaptopurine, asparaginase, pentamidine, didanosine, valproic acid, tetracyclines, dapsone, isoniazid, metronidazole
  • Infections: hepatitis viruses, mumps, cytomegalovirus, M avium intracellulare complex, SARS-CoV-2
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass

Explanation of other options:

Carotid dopplers (Option A): While carotid disease can cause cotton-wool spots, the context of acute pancreatitis with retinopathy, carotid evaluation is low yield in this scenario.

ERCP (Option C): Reserved for biliary obstruction or cholangitis. Not indicated unless imaging reveals biliary complications.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option D): Unrelated evidence of GI bleeding or peptic ulcer disease from the presentation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with longstanding epigastric pains. An abdominal CT was organised, and this showed dilated pancreatic ducts. The secretin test is positive. The patient has an HB of 13 g/dl, MCV of 105 fl and platelet count of 350 x 10^9/l. The high MCV is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In chronic pancreatitis, trypsin secretion is reduced. Trypsin is required in the release of protein-bound dietary B12, which enables absorption and hence B12 deficiency is the most likely in this case.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with epigastric pain and vomiting. He had pain located in the upper abdomen for the last 8 hours before admission. The patient also complained of nausea and two episodes of vomiting. He has an amylase of 500 (60-180) U/l. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed a pancreas with enhanced echogenicity. Which of the following is a poor prognostic indicator?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Poor prognostic indicators in acute pancreatitis can be assessed with the Ranson Criteria or APACHE scores.

Ranson's criteria:

At admission

  • Age in years > 55 years
  • White blood cell count > 16000 cells/mm3
  • Blood glucose (> 200 mg/dL)
  • Serum AST > 250 IU/L
  • serum LDH > 350 IU/L

At 48 hours

  • Calcium (serum calcium < 8.0 mg/dL)
  • Hematocrit fall > 10%
  • Oxygen (hypoxemia PO2 < 60 mmHg)
  • Urea increased by (5 or more mg/dL) after IV fluid hydration
  • Base deficit (negative base excess) > 4 mEq/L
  • Sequestration of fluids > 6L

Severity of Acute Pancreatitis:

  • Mild Acute Pancreatitis: no local complications or organ failure. Self-limiting disease. Recovery in 3-7 days.
  • Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis: Transient organ failure that resolves in < 48 hours. Or, local or systemic complications in the absence of organ failure.
  • Severe Acute Pancreatitis: Persistent Organ failure that lasts > 48 hours involving one or more organs.
  • With single organ failure, the mortality is 3-10%
  • With multi organ failure( severe acute pancreatitis), the mortality is nearly 50%

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with a six-month history of diarrhoea and pale stools. He has lost 1 stone in weight over the past 6 months. Investigations show:
Calcium 6.8 mg/dl
Phosphate 1.4 mg/dl
Alkaline phosphatase 360 U/L (45-105)
Stool for occult blood: negative
Faecal calprotectin: negative
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • With pale, fatty stools, weight loss, cholestatic pattern (↑ ALP, pale stools), and malabsorption-related hypocalcemia/hypophosphatemia, the picture aligns strongly with pancreatic carcinoma causing exocrine insufficiency and bile obstruction.
  • In chronic pancreatitis, trypsin secretion is reduced. Trypsin is required in the release of protein-bound dietary B12, which enables absorption and hence B12 deficiency is the most likely in this case.

Explanation of other options:

Amoebiasis(Option A): Amoebiasis presents as colitis (fever, bloody diarrhoea, blood loss anaemia) or may complicate to present as liver abscess (RUQ pain, vomiting, fever)

Whipple's disease(Option C): Whipple's disease presents with features of malabsorption along with arthritis, neurological features like confusion, opsoclonus, and dementia

Crohn's disease(Option D): Crohn's disease would present most commonly with ileocolitis (Right lower quadrant pain, blood in stools, fever). Faecal calprotectin is a sensitive noninvasive test used to screen for inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A man is admitted with acute abdominal pain and vomiting. He is diagnosed and treated for acute pancreatitis. Which of the following features is associated with a worse prognosis in acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Bedside Index of Severity in Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP)incorporates 5 clinical and laboratory parameters obtained within the first 24 hours of hospitalisation.

They are BUN >25 mg/dl, Impaired mental status, SIRS, age >60 and pleural effusion on radiography.

questions.text: Which of the following genotypes is associated with the lowest levels of alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • α-1antitrypsin deficiency is due to the insufficient plasma activity of the enzyme that degrades several proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G and proteinase 3.
  • It is an AR disease and is characterised by emphysema and cirrhosis.
  • The wild genotype is PiMM, seen in > 90% of individuals. The clinically significant mutation is PiZZ, which is associated with < 10% levels of the enzyme.
  • The null phenotype (not in the list of options) is the least common but the most severe form of the disease, where there is no detectable AAT in the serum.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The revised Atlanta classification requires that two or more of the following criteria be met for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis:

  • Abdominal pain consistent with acute pancreatitis (acute onset of a persistent, severe, epigastric pain often radiating to the back);
  • serum lipase activity (or amylase activity) at least three times greater than the upper limit of normal;
  • Characteristic findings of acute pancreatitis on contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) and, less commonly, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or transabdominal ultrasonography.

The Revised Atlanta Criteria define:

  • Phases of acute pancreatitis.
  • severity of acute pancreatitis, and
  • radiographic definitions

Explanation of other options:

Ranson criteria(Option A) are prognostic, used to estimate the severity and mortality risk, not for making the initial diagnosis.

Rome criteria(Option B) relate to functional gastrointestinal disorders (like IBS), not pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following organ systems is used to define organ failure in acute pancreatitis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Three organ systems should be assessed to define organ failure: respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal.

Organ failure is defined as a score of 2 or more for one of these three organ systems using the modified Marshall scoring system. Persistent organ failure (>48 h) is the most important clinical finding regarding the severity of the acute pancreatitis episode. Organ failure that affects more than one organ is considered multisystem organ failure. CT imaging is usually not needed or recommended during the first 48 hours of admission in acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the emergency department with features suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Which one of the following would you consider for his fluid management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Contains electrolytes (Na+, K+, Ca2+, lactate) closer to physiological levels, helping maintain pH and reducing acidosis compared to Normal Saline. (Option A ruled out.)
  • Lactated Ringer's solution has been shown to decrease systemic inflammation (lower C-reactive protein levels from admission) and may be a better crystalloid than normal saline.
  • Dextrose solutions are not suitable for initial resuscitation-they're hypotonic/sugar-containing and don't adequately expand intravascular volume. (Option C and D ruled out.)

Fluid management in acute pancreatitis:

  • Intravenous fluids of Lactated Ringer's or normal saline are initially bolused at 15-20 mL/kg (1050-1400 mL), followed by 2-3 mL/kg per hour (200-250 mL/h), to maintain urine output >0.5 mL/kg per hour.
  • Serial bedside evaluations are required every 6-8 h to assess vital signs, oxygen saturation, and change in physical examination to optimise fluid resuscitation.
  • A decrease in hematocrit and BUN during the first 12-24 h is strong evidence that sufficient fluids are being administered.d
  • A rise in hematocrit or BUN during serial measurement should be treated with a repeat volume challenge with a 2-L crystalloid bolus, followed by increasing the fluid rate by 1.5 mg/kg per hour.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male comes with a history of severe epigastric pain for the second time. His serum lipase levels are tenfold elevated. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a diffusely swollen pancreas, with a hypoechoic rim around it. Which of the following statements might not hold for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gentleman in this question has come with a second episode of pancreatitis. The imaging specifically depicts a hypoechoic rim.
  • Such a picture is seen in Autoimmune pancreatitis(AIP). This is called the capsule sign.

There are 2 types of AIP:

  • Type 1 and Type 2.
  • The response of both types of AIP to steroids is 100%.
  • Intraepithelial granulocytic lesion may be seen in Type 2 AIP(Option A ruled out)
  • Risk of relapse is there for Type 1 AIP(Option B ruled out)
  • The chance of other organ involvement is higher for type 1 AIP(Option C ruled out)
